column10: Awas struck by defendant who went through a red light.  The violent collision injured the plaintiff and her two sons and killed the youngest son.  The plaintiff suffered soft tissue injuries to her neck, left leg and lower back, headaches, pain in her back and her leg, fractures to her lumber spine.  She was left with ongoing back pain that limited all areas of her life.  In addition, she suffered mental and emotional distress as a result of the death of her son that would last her entire life.  The other plaintiffs (husband and two sons) suffered minor injuries, and a loss of guidance, care and compionship from their mother and deceased son and brother. ll five grounds of appeal dismissed. (1) Trial judge’s comments about the “threshold” regulation did not demonstrate bias. (2) Trial judge did not err in permitting an expert to rely on evidence from Statistics Canada. (3) Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. (4) The damages for loss of care, guidance and companionship under the Family Law Act was not excessive as to reflect an error in principle. (5) Trial judge’s costs awards were proportionate.

column10: Atwo sons and killed the youngest son.  The plaintiff suffered soft tissue injuries to her neck, left leg and lower back, headaches, pain in her back and her leg, fractures to her lumber spine.  She was left with ongoing back pain that limited all areas of her life.  In addition, she suffered mental and emotional distress as a result of the death of her son that would last her entire life.  The other plaintiffs (husband and two sons) suffered minor injuries, and a loss of guidance, care and compionship from their mother and deceased son and brother. ll five grounds of appeal dismissed. (1) Trial judge’s comments about the “threshold” regulation did not demonstrate bias. (2) Trial judge did not err in permitting an expert to rely on evidence from Statistics Canada. (3) Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. (4) The damages for loss of care, guidance and companionship under the Family Law Act was not excessive as to reflect an error in principle. (5) Trial judge’s costs awards were proportionate.

(3) Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. column10: P  PDefendant set plaintiff on fire and stabbed her. Plaintiff suffered third degree burns to 37% of her body, including to her face, chest, hands, fingers, lips, head, arms, ears, shoulders, upper back, neck, and nose. Plaintiff also suffered grade 3 inhalational injury to her lungs, requiring a left chest tube tracheotomy. Her scalp was burned, causing scarring and loss of hair. Both of her eyes were burned, causing damage to her vision. She lost part of her right ear, and also suffered significant hearing loss in that ear. laintiff has had more than 30 surgeries for debridement, skin graft surgeries, and reconstructive cosmetic surgeries including a right lower ear lobe reconstruction, right and left neck reconstruction, and left hand web space reconstruction. More surgery will likely be required.  laintiff suffers from depression, anxiety, nightmares, stress, constant fear, a deep sense of loss, and social anxiety. She has persistent pain and limitation of movement, permanent scarring and disfigurement, permanent physical restrictions, and is permanently unable to work in any capacity.

(1) Trial judge’s comments about the “threshold” regulation did not demonstrate bias. (2) Trial judge did not err in permitting an expert to rely on evidence from Statistics Canada. (3) Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. (4) The damages for loss of care, guidance and companionship under the Family Law Act was not excessive as to reflect an error in principle. (5) Trial judge’s costs awards were proportionate.

column10: (Appeal allowed:  (a)  The judgment was reduced by the sum of $44,583.90 to reflect an interest rate of 2.5% on the general damage award.  (b)  The obligation to assign the income replacement benefits payable by RSA Insurance should continue until the respondant’s 64th birthday.  (c)  The trial judge erred in in failing to instruct jury not to award any sum for drug benefits after plaintiff reached age of 65 because from that age forward, he would suffer no loss because his drug claims would be covered by Ontario Drug Benefit Program. d)  The trial judge erred in not ordering an assignment in relation to the awards for the cost of future medication and assistive devices and future professional services.

The plaintiff suffered soft tissue injuries to her neck, left leg and lower back, headaches, pain in her back and her leg, fractures to her lumber spine.  She was left with ongoing back pain that limited all areas of her life.  In addition, she suffered mental and emotional distress as a result of the death of her son that would last her entire life.  The other plaintiffs (husband and two sons) suffered minor injuries, and a loss of guidance, care and compionship from their mother and deceased son and brother. ll five grounds of appeal dismissed. (1) Trial judge’s comments about the “threshold” regulation did not demonstrate bias. (2) Trial judge did not err in permitting an expert to rely on evidence from Statistics Canada. (3) Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. (4) The damages for loss of care, guidance and companionship under the Family Law Act was not excessive as to reflect an error in principle. (5) Trial judge’s costs awards were proportionate.
